newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Guangshen Railway to cut domestic fares.
newsitem.headline: Guangshen Railway to cut domestic fares.

text.p: Guangshen Railway Co Ltd said it will lower fares on high-speed trains running Guangzhou-to-Shenzhen to the level before price were raised in Ocotber 1995 to enhance the railway's competitiveness.
But no fare changes were planned for the lucrative Guangzhou-to-Hong Kong through train, the company added.

From November 1, first class high-speed train fares will be cut by 22.22 percent to 70 yuan from 90 yuan and second-class fares by 18.75 percent to 65 yuan from 80 yuan, Guangshen said in a statement on Monday.
"After careful analysis of the market, Guangshen has decided to make domestic high speed fare reductions that are slightly larger than the company anticipated earlier this year," it said.
The company estimated about a 10 percent fare cut earlier.
It said it believed the cuts and its increased number of high speed trains would lift ridership and raise Guangshen's competitiveness against other means of transportation.
The Chinese railway operator experienced a decline on passenger and freights volumes earlier this year due to a ticket price rise and competition from buses.
The company said it hoped the fares cut could help reverse the decline of passenger volume.
"Guangshen's high speed project is a critical part of the company strategy," it said.
Guangshen also said on November 1, it would reach the target of 19 round-trip high speed passenger trains operating daily between Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and Guangzhou and Hong Kong's Kowloon.
It has increased the frequency of its trains to 47 pairs per day from 36 per day since the beginning of 1996, the railway operator said.
